title: Extreme Misophonia and Hyperacusis in a Young Adult
chief_complaint: I have extreme sensitivity to specific sounds like chewing, eating, and silverware scraping. It makes me physically uncomfortable and angry, and I sometimes hurt myself to cope.

problem_summary.onset: Specific onset age not reported, but previous audiology encounter at age 4 was normal.
problem_summary.course: Current state is extreme/severe; triggers are worse when created by family members. Condition worsened at 1-year follow-up despite sound therapy intervention.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Obsessive concern with germs, refusal to touch hands, meticulousness about order/arrangement, self-mutilating behaviors (scratching hands/wrists).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant negative impact on activities, thoughts, and feelings; resorts to self-harm; unable to remove himself from triggering situations without distress. At 1-year follow-up, unable to tolerate clinical waiting room and could only communicate via text message.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Patient denies knowing how injuries occurred; family is protective and resistant to mental health labeling.

history.present_illness: Patient reports extreme sensitivity to specific sounds (talking, chewing, eating, silverware). Reactions include physical discomfort and anger. Patient resorts to digging fingernails into hands/wrists.
history.otologic_history: Previous audiology exam at age 4 was normal.
history.medical_psych_history: Obsessive behaviors regarding germs and order. 'Gets lost in own complex creations'. Memory for 200 'super-powers' of toy cars. Parents resistant to psychological referral.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally. PTA is 12 dB HL in each ear. Thresholds obtained from 250 to 20,000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition scores consistent with normal hearing sensitivity.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear function bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Could not test (CNT) due to patient's extreme sound hypersensitivity.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDL)
tests.key_findings: Reduced loudness tolerance. LDLs measured between 60 and 80 dB HL for pure tones and 75 dB HL for speech.

tests.name: Self-Report Scales
tests.key_findings: Scores indicate extreme misophonia and severe impact on quality of life. Patient rated annoyance 10/10.

history.present_illness: Patient arrived in acute distress, had to be removed from waiting room due to inability to tolerate sound sensitivity. 'Triggered' on the drive to the clinic and was only able to communicate by text message to parent. Not consistently utilizing sound therapy devices.
history.medical_psych_history: Has not seen a mental health professional. Parents remain concerned about JM 'being labeled.' Never prescribed medication or treatment plan for any possible mental health disorder.
history.prior_management: Fitted with bilateral Resound LINX2 5 RIC hearing aids with 'water creek' sound therapy at V1. Seen on three occasions for hearing aid repairs and maintenance. Inconsistent use of sound therapy.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: No change in pure-tone air conduction thresholds from baseline. Normal hearing sensitivity maintained.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDL)
tests.key_findings: Markedly decreased LDLs compared to baseline (35-50 dB HL vs. 60-80 dB HL), indicating significant worsening of loudness tolerance. Note: Patient's distressed state upon arrival may have contributed to the significant decrease.

tests.name: Self-Report Scales
tests.key_findings: Scores indicate worsening of misophonia severity. MAQ increased from 51 to 60; A-MISO-S increased from 19 to 21. Both scores remain in the extreme category.

treatment_and_management.current_status: Sound therapy not being utilized consistently. No measurable improvement in managing sound sensitivities.
treatment_and_management.patient_reported_outcomes: Sound therapy, when utilized, helped patient function while with friends in noisy environments. Little improvement noted when exposed to trigger sounds around family.
management_decisions: Reinforced importance of consistent sound therapy use
Discussed additional intervention needed to address possibility of underlying psychological disorders
Addressed parent inquiry about anxiety medication - advised to discuss with physician
Counseled on challenges JM may face in academic, social, and communal living settings of college
treatment_and_management.referrals: Mental health referral strongly re-recommended; family continues to decline

indicators: LDL decreased by 20-35 dB HL from baseline
Patient unable to tolerate clinical waiting room
Communication limited to text messaging only during acute episode
contributing_factors: Inconsistent use of sound therapy devices
No mental health intervention despite strong recommendations

next_steps: Continue ear-level sound therapy with emphasis on consistent daily use
Re-evaluate LDL and questionnaire scores at next follow-up
Encourage family to reconsider mental health referral
Support transition planning for college environment
follow_up_plan.recommended_interval: As-needed basis for hearing aid maintenance
barriers_to_care: Family resistance to mental health referral

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal peripheral hearing sensitivity bilaterally and normal middle ear function. However, Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDLs) are significantly reduced, consistent with hyperacusis. At baseline (September 2016), LDLs were 60-80 dB HL; at 1-year follow-up (November 2017), LDLs markedly worsened to 35-50 dB HL. Questionnaire results confirm the presence of extreme misophonia with worsening impact on daily life: MAQ score increased from 51 to 60, and A-MISO-S score increased from 19 to 21. Despite fitting with ear-level sound therapy devices, the patient has not shown measurable improvement due to inconsistent use and lack of mental health intervention.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows your ears are physically healthy and you hear very well.
The distress you feel is real; we call this misophonia (reaction to specific sounds) and hyperacusis (sensitivity to volume).
We can use sound therapy (ear-level devices) to help 'cushion' the trigger sounds, making them less sharp and bothersome.
It is important to have control over the sound therapy and use it to gradually build tolerance.
Sound therapy must be used consistently for measurable improvements to be seen.
Given the high level of distress, working with a mental health professional for strategies to manage the emotional reaction is strongly recommended.
notes_for_actor: Portray an 18-year-old who is visibly anxious or tense, especially if background noises occur.
You are meticulous and may refuse to shake hands due to germ concerns.
If asked about the scratches on your hands/wrists, deny knowing how they happened or be evasive.
Show reliance on your parent, who accompanies you.
You are intelligent (remembering complex details about toys) but socially guarded.
